steps: Remove Chemical – Brush off dry chemicals, take off contaminated clothes/jewelry (unless stuck).
Rinse with Water – Flush skin or eyes with cool running water right away. Keep rinsing 20+ minutes.
Cover Burn – Use a clean, dry, non-fluffy cloth or sterile gauze. Keep it loose.
Do NOT Apply Anything – No vinegar, creams, oils, toothpaste, butter, or neutralizers.
Get Emergency Help – Call for help if burn is large, deep, on face/eyes/hands/feet/genitals, victim is very young/old, or unconscious. Take chemical container/label if safe.
Chemical.key_rule: Flush with water fast and keep flushing until help arrives.

steps: Cool the Burn – Run under cool water for 20 minutes (or use a clean wet cloth). No ice.
Apply Lotion (Minor Burns Only) – Use aloe-vera or petroleum jelly. No butter, oils, toothpaste.
Cover the Burn – Loosely with cling film, clean plastic, or sterile gauze. Don’t remove stuck clothing.
Seek Emergency Help If: Burn is large/deep, or on face, hands, feet, genitals, joints. Burn from chemicals, electricity, or explosion. Victim is very young, elderly, or unwell.
Thermal.key_rule: Cool with water, cover, and call for help if serious.

steps: Use F.A.S.T. to help remember warning signs:
Face – Does the face droop on one side when the person tries to smile?
Arms – Is one arm lower when the person tries to raise both arms? Is one arm weak or numb?
Speech – Can the person repeat a simple sentence? Is speech slurred or hard to understand?
Time – Every minute counts during a stroke. Call 911 or your local emergency number right away if you see any of these signs.
Stroke.key_rule: Do not give food, drink, or medicine until a doctor says so — swallowing may be impaired.

steps: Check Responsiveness – Tap their shoulder, shout 'Are you okay?'
Call for Help – Dial emergency services immediately.
Start CPR: Place heel of one hand in the center of the chest. Push hard and fast (100–120 per minute). Allow chest to rise fully between compressions.
Keep going until emergency responders arrive or the person starts moving/breathing.
Cardiac_Arrest.key_rule: Don’t stop until medical help arrives or the person starts breathing/moving.

steps: Stop the bleeding – Cover the wound with sterile gauze or a clean cloth. Press firmly until bleeding stops.
Help the injured person lie down – Place on a rug/blanket to prevent heat loss. Elevate feet if signs of shock appear.
Keep Still & Await Help – Do not move. When help arrives, inform them how long pressure/tourniquet has been applied.
Keep the person still – Lay down with head/shoulders slightly elevated. Avoid moving the neck. Do not remove helmet.
Stop any bleeding – Apply firm pressure with sterile gauze/cloth. Do not press if skull fracture suspected.
Watch for breathing/alertness – If no breathing/circulation, begin CPR.
Head_Trauma.key_rule: Do not move the head; keep airway open and get emergency help fast.

steps: Encourage coughing if partial blockage.
If severe, give up to 5 back blows while bending them forward.
If still choking – perform up to 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich).
If unresponsive – Call emergency help, start CPR, check airway after compressions.
Choking.key_rule: Do not blindly sweep the mouth with fingers; it can push object deeper.

steps: Make scene safe – Use reach/row rescue if possible; only enter water if trained and safe.
Check responsiveness & breathing (10 sec). If breathing normally → recovery position. If not → CPR.
Begin rescue breathing with compressions: 30 chest compressions, then 2 rescue breaths. Continue cycle.
Stay calm – Move objects away, cushion head, loosen tight clothes.
Do not restrain or put anything in mouth. Time the seizure.
After seizure stops – place in recovery position if breathing.
Call emergency help if seizure lasts >5 mins, repeats, first-time, happens in water, injured, pregnant, diabetic, or if breathing doesn’t return.
Stay until help arrives, be ready for CPR if needed.
Do not move person – Keep as found. Align head/neck with rolled towels if possible.
Control bleeding without moving neck. Keep warm and still.
If airway must be opened, use jaw-thrust (not head-tilt).
If unresponsive & not breathing – start CPR carefully minimizing neck movement.
Remove source safely.
Swallowed: clear mouth of poison remains.
Skin exposure: remove clothes, rinse skin with water 15–20 min.
Eye exposure: flush eyes with water for 15–20 min.
If vomiting – turn head sideways. Do not induce vomiting.
Call Poison Help or Emergency Services immediately.
Conscious.key_rule: Call for help first, rinse if exposed, turn on side if vomiting, never force vomiting.

steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Check airway, breathing, pulse → if absent, begin CPR.
Do not give food, drink, or remedies.
Collect poison containers/labels for EMS.
